Award.AwardTitle: Transforming STEM Teaching in a Large Urban-Serving University

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Through this WIDER planning grant, the University of South Florida (USF) is developing a comprehensive and feasible implementation plan for a faculty-directed program of interventions that will increase undergraduate student persistence and success in STEM courses and enhance STEM degree production, particularly among Hispanics, African-Americans, and women. To do so, USF is creating strategies to secure adoption of evidence-based STEM teaching practices customized for three distinct groups: tenure-line and tenured faculty; contingent faculty; and graduate teaching assistants. The Transforming STEM Teaching in a Large Urban-Serving University (TST@USF) project uses a top down/bottom up convergence model to provide leadership that is shared by administrators and faculty. This model assures buy-in by faculty and support and resources by the administration. The work plan includes a comprehensive data-based analysis of current student outcomes, faculty practices, and system supports and barriers. It advances knowledge of evidence-based STEM teaching practices and of leadership for change, and establishes a shared vision and commitment to implementation.

TST@USF is developing a plan to establish a highly replicable set of strategies that will lead faculty, instructors, and teaching assistants to use teaching practices whose effectiveness in retaining students in the STEM disciplines is documented by past research evidence. TST@USF places special emphasis on Hispanic, African-American, and female students whose STEM participation rate is considerably lower than that of white males. It is achieving project goals by employing a model of leadership for change that is shared between faculty and administrators.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) areas are now among the most popular majors in college, however, fewer than 40% of students who start in a STEM major typically finish in that major. This compounds the problem of a need for more STEM graduates to meet the demands of the 21st century economy. The project addressed this need by developing a comprehensive plan to bring about widespread use of more effective teaching strategies. These evidence-based active learning approaches to teaching will lead to improved learning, greater retention, and graduation in STEM degrees. The plan also addressed the contextual elements such as facilities (spaces that facilitate active learning) and policies (such as reward structures and student evaluations) that will support the transition from lecture based teaching approaches to more active learning formats. 

A leadership team of twelve diverse individuals led this project and met biweekly throughout the grant period. This group carried the major responsibility for development of the plan and subsequent successful implementation proposal. The diversity of disciplinary backgrounds, knowledge, and expertise of the group with effective teaching strategies, effective professional development, university culture and policies were key to producing the plan. Guidance from a talented external advisory board and our evaluator also were essential in refining and focusing the final plan and grant proposal.

The final outcomes of the planning grant are:

 

  • A plan for transforming STEM instruction at a research I university and one of its partner community colleges
  • A process for developing a collaborative and comprehensive approach and the rational for each element of the plan
  • A successful grant application to the National Science Foundation to implement the plan
